title: High Bribery Incidence Among Firms
description: In 2017, 56.1% of firms in Liberia reported experiencing at least one bribe payment request, indicating a significant challenge in the business environment.

title: Significant Net Forest Depletion
description: In 2021, Liberia's adjusted savings due to net forest depletion was 17.54% of GNI, highlighting environmental sustainability concerns.

title: Low Access to Basic Handwashing Facilities
description: As of 2022, only 3.44% of Liberia's population had access to basic handwashing facilities, underscoring public health challenges.

title: Limited New Business Density
description: In 2022, Liberia had a new business density of 0.0245 registrations per 1,000 people aged 15-64, indicating a low rate of entrepreneurship.

title: Low GDP and GNI Per Capita
description: In 2023, Liberia's GDP per capita was 771.89 LCU, and GNI per capita was 722.19 LCU, reflecting economic challenges.

title: High Rate of Over-Age Female Students in Primary Education
description: In 2017, 46.53% of female students in primary education were over-age, indicating educational system inefficiencies.

title: Limited Urban Handwashing Facilities
description: In 2022, only 5.64% of Liberia's urban population had access to basic handwashing facilities, highlighting urban health infrastructure issues.

title: Low Military Expenditure
description: In 2023, Liberia's military expenditure was 37,153,000 LCU, reflecting limited investment in defense.

title: Limited Transport Services in Service Exports
description: In 2022, transport services accounted for only 0.39% of Liberia's service exports, indicating a narrow service export base.

title: Low Value Added per Worker in Services
description: In 2023, the value added per worker in Liberia's service sector was 1,004.08 constant 2015 US$, indicating low productivity.

title: Limited Voice and Accountability
description: In 2023, Liberia had 14 sources for voice and accountability, suggesting challenges in governance and civic engagement.

title: Minimal Official Flows from UN Agencies
description: In 2022, Liberia received 136.50 US$ in net official flows from UN agencies, indicating limited international financial support.
